answers.answer: Possible it's related to your back problems if the arthritis or disc problems are extensive to affect both legs.  Or it sounds like you may be developing a peripheral neuropathy (separate from the back pain) which is an abnormality of the nerves to the limbs.  There's a very long list of things that can cause this such as diabetes and alcohol.  Further evaluation can be done with blood testing and possibly an EMG to lookat the integrity of the nerves.  This can also help determine if there is nerve damage from the disc disease.  Talk to your doctor about getting a neuro referral and possibly an EMG. GOod luck.

question: I am 72 years of age.In excellent health.I have been a runner, 5 to 10 miles for 35 years.Since a fall while running 2 years ago I have had back pain.X-Rays and MRI have revealed disc problems and some arthritis.My doctor recommended I continue running or at least walking and I still run, inside and outside.I've noticed that my problems are least evident and I feel my best when I am running and immediately after.I always have some discomfort, mild pain in my lower back and that sometimes moves into my upper leg or legs.The past year I have been experiencing numbness in my feet.  At first it was just the sole of one foot.  Now it affects my entire right foot and the left one to a lesser extent.Please tell me what's happening and what can be done?
title: Foot numbness from back problems
